stephen weinberg was a nobel laureate
statesman of science and voice of reason
he was universally regarded as one of
the greatest thinkers
of our age
[Music]
i first met stephen weinberg back in
about
1986 when i was a a graduate student at
harvard and was invited to give a talk
at the university
of texas austin where professor weinberg
was the head of the theoretical physics
group
now i almost never get
nervous before talks but this time
knowing that stephen weinberg would be
in the audience i was seriously nervous
i mean so much of my outlook on physics
had been
shaped by professor weinberg's writings
i mean when i was in
in high school i'd i read and re-read
his book the
first three minutes and in college his
textbook
gravitation and cosmology principles and
applications of the general theory of
relativity well
that textbook had been a kind of
companion to me i i
purchased it after a lecture by stephen
hawking got me
all fired up about space and time
cosmology relativity and all that and
and i i desperately wanted to understand
all the math
and all the ideas but back then i was
still a couple years away from having
the necessary
background so i simply carried
the textbook around with me everywhere
stephen weinberg was
always in my backpack and when
no one was around i'd sometimes take out
the text admire it's
it's rich blue cover sometimes running
my fingers over the title and
and when later on i finally was able to
dive in and
understand the material i felt like i'd
journey through the cosmos with the
rigorous but
crystal clear stephen weinberg as my
personal guide so
you can understand how going to texas to
give a talk and
meet weinberg in person was for me quite
the moment well the talk went off
without a hitch
but it was my conversation with stephen
weinberg
just after the talk which really stuck
with me
in my graduate student eagerness i had
thoroughly stuffed the talk with complex
equations
but with great tact after the talk
professor weinberg
gave me his own down-to-earth version of
many of the points that i had made
myself in the talk it was a
it's a virtuosic demonstration of
weinberg's
hallmark capacity to see through
complexity and reveal
the essence of ideas a capacity for
which stephen weinberg
was the unmatched master
with stephen weinberg's passing we have
lost not only a giant of science but an
extraordinarily erudite
thoughtful and sharp-witted observer of
the human condition
he was a great friend to the world
science festival
appearing many times in our programs
which allows us now
to hear from him in his own words
reflecting on
science life the state of the world
and where things are going from here
professor weinberg's own journey began
simply like many theoretical physicists
from an early age he could feel the
strange and wondrous
power of mathematics to illuminate
reality
i grew up in a modest family i was the
first to go to college
i found to my amazement teaching myself
some
physics and mathematics in high school
that you could do powerful things with
this intellectual apparatus i remember
calculating the shape of the cables that
hold up a
suspension bridge it's a catenary and
deriving the equation for a catenary
i thought uh wow you know i'm not
building a bridge but i can
see why it takes the shape it does and
uh that sense of the power of
mathematical reasoning
was intoxicating and of course
calculating the shape of a suspension
bridge cables was nothing new
and there was nothing i could publish
about it but um
uh i love the the intellectual power
and then eventually found i could
do something myself i it took me a long
time actually i wasn't at all precocious
in college the idea of doing anything
new
seemed infinitely difficult because
there was all that work
out there that had already been done and
i hadn't learned it all and i thought
you had to learn everything in order to
do anything new and then
uh when my wife and i got married we
decided
for purely romantic reasons to spend our
first year in europe and i
i went to the niels bohr institute at
copenhagen with a bag of books
that i was going to read again thinking
i wasn't going to do anything original
and they said well no everybody here is
doing research you've got to start doing
research
i said you're kidding i don't know how
to do anything new
and one of the professors there who
died recently gunnar chalain
actually suggested a research problem
and
i didn't know much about the subject but
by god i could do the problem and
didn't got a paper published and so
by the time i arrived back in graduate
school at princeton
i felt like a grown-up and
i'd made that transition from being a
student to being a grown-up
and um uh it was
it was really uh a difficult transition
which
you know it's like getting rid of your
skin like a snake getting rid of their
skin
uh but it's it's gone pretty well since
then
after making that difficult transition
from student to researcher
some scientists are content to drill
ever more deeply in the circumscribed

completely
different tack drilling deep for sure
but
also constantly surveying the

observing and appreciating dependencies

that had escaped earlier generations of

and among these was the recognition that

point toward the most fundamental and

but to our understanding of nature at
all

is this is governed by a unified set of

but that physics and chemistry

and even biology is strongly influenced

there's no biological law that says

that's a consequence of

which was really only on although it was

so i think that's a big thing you know
at the turn of the

i couldn't understand how anyone could

of course physicists had not succeeded

why uh sodium and chlorine

something for the guy down the hall
and i the unity of science is something

we've learned i guess you could say

that there are separate independent
principles
of physics of chemistry of biology

with that unlearning of the natural but

equal claim of being fundamental finding
the laws that undergird
the most fundamental of sciences physics
that becomes all the more pressing

single coherent mathematical formulation

in its more modern formulation a unified
field theory would establish that
all of nature's forces are merely

of a single all-encompassing super force
famously after ardently pursuing this

einstein came up empty-handed
taking a different approach stephen
weinberg was able to bring this dream of

one step closer he proposed
that two of nature's forces the
electromagnetic force which is
responsible for all
electric and magnetic phenomenon and the
weak
nuclear force responsible for
radioactive decay he proposed
that they are actually different facets

in the 1970s a series of experiments
